qas.question: What European country did the Dominican Friars quickly expand to?
What British university did the Dominican Friars appear in?
What did the Dominican Order fight against?
What is one branch of knowledge that the Dominican Order created works in?
Who appointed the Dominican Order to begin the inquisition?
What order did not quickly spread through England?

plausible_answers.text: reached all classes of Christian society, fought heresy, schism, and paganism by word and book, and by its missions to the north of Europe, to Africa, and Asia

qas.question: What happened to the order in the 14th century?
What French university did the Dominican friars appear in?
What are the three branches of knowledge that the Dominican Order created works in?
Who appointed the Benedictine Order to begin the inquisition?

context: The <b5_0>Dominican friars<b5_0/> quickly spread, including to <a0_0>England<a0_0/>, where they appeared in <a1_0><b7_0>Oxford<b7_0/><a1_0/> in 1221. In the 13th century the order <b6_0>reached all classes of Christian society, fought heresy, schism, and <a2_0>paganism<a2_0/> by word and book, and by its missions to the north of Europe, to Africa, and Asia<b6_0/> passed beyond the frontiers of Christendom. Its schools spread throughout the entire Church; its doctors wrote monumental works in all branches of knowledge, including the extremely important <b8_0>Albertus Magnus and <a3_0>Thomas Aquinas<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Its members included popes, cardinals, bishops, legates, inquisitors, confessors of princes, ambassadors, and paciarii (enforcers of the peace decreed by popes or councils). The order was appointed by <a4_0><b9_0>Pope Gregory IX<b9_0/><a4_0/> the duty to carry out the Inquisition. In his Papal Bull Ad extirpanda of 1252, Pope Innocent IV authorised the Dominicans' use of torture under prescribed circumstances.
